p: In the fall of 2012, individuals travelling from the Arabian Peninsula to the United Kingdom were affected by the Middle-East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), a severe lower respiratory tract infection that resembled SARS, leading also to gastrointestinal symptoms and renal failure among some patients [ 221]. Molecular sequencing rapidly showed that the new epidemic was caused by a new coronavirus: the MERS-CoV [ 193, 222, 223]. MERS-CoV most probably originated from bats before infecting an intermediary reservoir (the dromedary camel), and also represented a zoonotic transmission to humans. Phylogenetic analyses suggest that there have been multiple independent zoonotic introductions of the virus in the human population. Moreover, nosocomial transmission was observed in multiple hospitals in Saudi Arabia [ 221, 224, 225, 226, 227, 228, 229, 230].
